title: John Lennon’s least favourite Beatles song is one he ‘knocked off’ from Elvis
text:
The Beatles are still thought of as the biggest band in the world (Picture: Getty)

The Beatles are still widely known thought of as the biggest band in the world, recording some of the most recognised music in history.

The band – made up of John Lennon, Paul McCartney, Ringo Starr and George Harrison – were known as the Fab Four, and blessed us with hits including Let It Be, Here Comes The Sun and Hey Jude.

So. Many. Bangers.

However, there is one track in particular that John really wasn’t a fan of, Run For Your Life.

In fact, the late star – who died in 1980, aged 40 – went so far as to brand the track, which appears on the Rubber Soul album, his ‘least favourite Beatles song’.

Judging by the fact they made well over 100 songs, that’s saying a lot.

John Lennon hated Run For Your Life (Picture: Getty)

The song borrows a lyric from Elvis’ Baby Let’s Play House, which references wanting to kill a girlfriend if she’s unfaithful.

And speaking about the line, he admitted he ‘knocked off’ the whole thing.

‘Run for Your Life, I always hated, you know,’ he told Rolling Stone back in 1970. ‘I never liked Run For Your Life, because it was a song I just knocked off.

‘It was inspired from – this is a very vague connection – from Baby Let’s Play House. There was a line on it, I used to like specific lines from songs, “I’d rather see you dead, little girl, than to be with another man” – so I wrote it around that but I didn’t think it was that important.’

But while the song has gone on to divide fans around the world, John revealed there was one member of the Fab Four who liked it – George.

Discussing the track three years later, he added: ‘Just a sort of throwaway song of mine that I never thought much of, but it was always a favourite of George’s.’

While Paul branded it a ‘bit of a macho song’.

He does have a point…

The Fab Four recorded some of the most recognised music in history (Picture: Getty)

Paul and Ringo recently got back into the studio together to cover one of John’s songs, as a tribute to the late star – who was assassinated in December, 1980.

Announcing his version of Grow Old With Me, Ringo said: ‘I sang it the best that I could.

‘I do well up when I think of John this deeply. And I’ve done my best. We’ve done our best.

‘The other good thing is that I really wanted Paul to play on it, and he said yes.

‘Paul came over and he played bass and sings a little bit on this with me. So John’s on it in a way. I’m on it and Paul’s on it.’

Ringo isn’t leaving George out, as a line from Here Comes The Sun – which the late star penned – is also used.

He added: ‘So in a way, it’s the four of us.’
